eigenerr_test.cpp

Calculates the relative error of one eigenvalue with no. "c". Given a symmetric matrix amatA, the matrix vmatA of its eigenvectors and the vector dvecA of the corresponding eigenvalues, this function calculates the relative error of one eigenvalue, denoted by the no. c. If we have a matrix A, a matrix x of eigenvectors and a vector of corresponding eigenvalues, the relative error of eigenvalue no. c is calculated as

Parameters:
amatA  matrix, which has to be symmetric, so only the lower triangular matrix must contain values. The matrix is not changed by the function.
vmatA  matrix with normalized eigenvectors, each column contains an eigenvector.
dvecA n-dimensional vector with eigenvalues in descending order.
c No. of the considered eigenvalue.
Returns:
the relative error.
Exceptions:
check_exception the type of the exception will be "size mismatch" and indicates that dvecA is not one-dimensional or that amatA or vmatA don't have the same number of rows or columns as dvecA contains number of values
Please follow the link to view the source code of the example. The example can be executed in the example directory of package LinAlg.

Author:
M. Kreutz
Date:
1998
Changes
none
Status
stable
00001 //===========================================================================
00051 //===========================================================================
00052 #include <iostream>
00053 #include "Array/ArrayIo.h"
00054 #include "LinAlg/linalg.h"
00055 
00056 using namespace std;
00057 
00058 int main() 
00059 {
00060     Array2D< double > A(3,3);    // input matrix
00061     Array2D< double > x(3,3);    // matrix for eigenvectors
00062     Array  < double > lambda(3); // vector for eigenvalues
00063     unsigned          curr_row,  // currently considered matrix
00064                       curr_col;  // row/column
00065     double            error(0.); // relative error
00066 
00067     // Initialization values for input matrix:
00068     double bottom_triangle[9] = 
00069     { 
00070          7.,  0.,  0., 
00071 
00072         -2.,  6.,  0., 
00073 
00074          0., -2.,  0. 
00075     };
00076 
00077     // Initializing matrices and vector:
00078     for (curr_row = 0; curr_row < 3; curr_row++)
00079     {
00080         for (curr_col = 0; curr_col < 3; curr_col++)
00081         {
00082                 A(curr_row, curr_col) = bottom_triangle[curr_row*3+curr_col];
00083                 x(curr_row, curr_col) = 0.;
00084         }
00085             lambda(curr_row) = 0.;
00086     }
00087 
00088     // Output of input matrix:
00089     cout << "input matrix:" << endl;
00090     writeArray(A, cout);
00091 
00092     // Calculating eigenvalues and eigenvectors:
00093     //eigensymm(A, x, lambda);// A is unchanged after the call
00094     eigensymm_obsolete(A, x, lambda);// A is corrupted after the call
00095 
00096     // Output of eigenvectors and eigenvalues:
00097     cout << "matrix of eigenvectors:" << endl;
00098     writeArray(x, cout);
00099     cout << "vector of eigenvalues:" << endl;
00100     writeArray(lambda, cout);
00101 
00102     cout << endl;
00103     // Calculating relative errors for all eigenvalues:
00104     for (curr_row = 0; curr_row < 3; curr_row++)
00105     {
00106         error = eigenerr(A, x, lambda, curr_row);
00107         cout << "error of eigenvalue " << lambda(curr_row) << " = "
00108              << error << endl;
00109     }
00110 
00111     return 0;
00112 }
